citation.article-title: Taxonomy of the glycerol fermenting clostridia and description of Clostridium diolis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Clostridium diolis sp. nov.
Clostridium diolis (di.o'.lis. N.L. neutr. n. gen. diolis, of a diol (producing a diol))
Cell morphology resembles C. butyricum and C. beijerinckii, i. e. 0.7–1.7 × 1.2–8 m, singly or in pairs, occasionally in filaments.
Spores oval, terminal or subterminal, swell the cell.
Gram-positive, becoming Gram-negative in older cultures.

A large variety of carbohydrates and carbohydrate derivatives including glucose, fructose, cellobiose, lactose, galactose, trehalose, xylose, salicin, amygdalin, melibiose, glycogen, mannitol and glycerol are fermented.
Melizitose, arabinose, ribose, esculin and sorbitol are weakly used.
In contrast to C. beijerinckii raffinose, starch and m-inositol are not used.
Strains can be further distinguished from C. beijerinckii by their ability to grow in a glucose-mineral medium with biotin as the only growth factor.

They can be distinguished from C. butyricum by their inability to grow in yeast extract-peptone medium without a fermentable carbon source and additionally by fermenting mannitol, sorbitol, arabinose and melizitose, but not starch and raffinose.
Fermentation products from glucose are butyrate and acetate, from glycerol 1,3-propanediol in addition to butyrate and acetate.
Type strain: Strain SH1, isolated from decaying straw and deposited as DSM 5431 [4] and ATCC BAA-557 (accession no.).
